Greg Wise: biography, family, career

The actor was born on May 15, 1966 as Matthew Gregory Wise in Newcastle upon Tyne, England. He was born the son of architect parents Douglass Wise and Yvonne Jeannine Czeiler. Wise has a British nationality and belongs to the white ethnicity. He has not provided information about his siblings. As for his education, he attended the independent St Peter’s School, York. After that, he went to Heriot-Watt University in Edinburgh to study architecture and acted in the Bedlam Theatre. In addition, he had enrolled to study theater at the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama.

He began his professional stage career and appeared in a musical based on the life of television producer Jack Good called Good Rockin’ Tonight. Since 1992, she has worked in various TV shows and movies. He made his movie debut in 1995 as Arch Wilson in Feast of July. After that, he has worked on many movies including 1997’s The Moonstone, 2001’s The Discovery of Heaven, 2003’s Johnny English, 2005’s A Cock and Bull Story, 2013’s Effie Gray and 2018’s ‘A Private War’.

His television credits in 1992 A Masculine Ending, 1994 Taggart, 1997 The Place of the Dead, 2005 According to Bex, 2009 Cranford, 2011 Law & Order: the UK, 2016 The Crown and 2018 Strange Angel. In addition, he also emerged as a producer on the 2010 BBC/Masterpiece production The Song of Lunch, starring his wife Emma Thompson and Alan Rickman.

Greg Wise: personal life and girlfriend

As for his personal life, he has married the British actress, screenwriter and producer Emma Thompon. The couple first met on the set of “Sense and Sensibility” in 1995. At the time, his wife was still married to her ex-husband, actor-director Kenneth Branagh. Emma and Kenneth were together from 1989 to 1995.

Furthermore, the duo exchanged vows in 2003 and as of now, they live at their permanent residence in West Hampstead, London. The couple have a seven-year age difference between them. They also had a daughter, Gaia, in 1999 through IVF. In addition, they informally adopted Tindyebwa Agaba, a Rwandan orphan and former child soldier in 2003, the year they were married.
